I live in Hounslow which is mostly immigrants and immigrant descendants including me. People from here have joined ISIS and yeah there have been a lot of stabbings in my area through the years. Lived here for 21 years, went to school here and had a job here, and yeah generally found my generation are pretty agnostic. Went to a religious school were nearly everyone didn't believe in anything and pretty much is the same with our parents. Maybe because it's multicultural the young are just sick of religion, and most people who are religious don't let it define their entire personality. So yeah London is pretty tolerant in general, you can see how it's different through the way it votes in general and in the EU referendum. By the sounds of it your only been here once and just believe the stereotypes about 'stabbing' happening every minute in every part of London and acid attacks. (Funny I actually saw a daily mail headline talking about kids using acid instead of knives now-you probably just read that- I doubt you live here)
Where I live is pretty bad for crime and poverty but it's still not like that - this real enough for you?

It's pretty much one of the most tolerant places - and the best part is nearly everyone is agnostic and the press is currently destroying a leading politician who keeps avoiding the question if gay sex is a sin-can be pretty great here sometimes but hope it all goes okay with you in the US

I much prefer running on a treadmill. Doesn't matter what time of day it is if the gym is open, the gradient doesn't fluctuate unless you want it too, you can measure your speed better, don't have to carry a bag, don't have to wrap up warm, or avoid cars, or pedestrians. Yeah it can be boring but running outside is good every once in a while for the fresh air and maybe scenery but I feel the toll it takes on your body (well mine anyway) is a lot worse). WRITING.TITLE: Made a video on how WWII should differentiate itself from other COD's and World War shooters by making a mature campaign in lesser known battles and theatres of war
The Gaming Bible (offshoot of the Lad Bible) used a clip from by Youtube Channel, didn't credit me and claim they don't have to-who is in the right?
WRITING.TEXT:
I posted a clip of me hunting on Horizon Zero Dawn. I posted to Reddit and YouTube and numerous gaming sites asked me if they could use it and they would credit me-Of course I let them. Now I received a message from a sub today telling me it was in the Gaming Bible without my knowledge or credit. Obviously angry I asked them why. Their response:
''Because the clip is purely gameplay, and hasn't been edited, everything in it belongs to the developers and artists who created the game and in turn so does the clip. We always make sure we ask permission for clips that people have edited or narrated, but in certain cases it's not necessary''
The did say they'd put my name in now but the video has already got 600k views, 369 shares, thousands of likes and comments, which obviously generates them revenue. My clip was pretty skilful so a standard clip of Horizon would not have generated this much attention-who is in the right? It's standard practice to credit someone right?
